news-item.title: IN BRIEF; BELGIUM War shell kills; FRANCE Leader's son charged; GREECE Sackings strike; TURKEY Killer train crash; AFGHANISTAN Poll suicide assault
news-item.text: Two workers died when a World War I shell exploded near the Belgian town of Ypres, site of some of the bloodiest battles in the conflict. Two other men were hurt, one left fighting for his life France has charged the son of Equatorial Guinea's President Teodoro Obiang Nguema with money laundering. Teodorin Obiang was charged on Wednesday as part of a corruption probe launched in 2010. Greek public servants have launched a 48-hour strike against more lay-offs planned this year under the terms of the country's European Union-IMF bailout. Greece is required to sack 11,500 public servants this year. A passenger train crashed into a minibus carrying workers to a factory at a level crossing near the Mediterranean port city of Mersin yesterday, killing 10 people in the vehicle and injuring five, officials said. Seven Taliban suicide attackers have stormed a police building in eastern Afghanistan, killing 10 officers. The Taliban has vowed to disrupt next month's presidential election.
